title: In Parliament Ley stated ‘radical Islamist extremism caused’ the Bondi massacre
description: Opposition Leader Sussan Ley gave condolences to the Bondi Beach massacre victims.  “I join with all members of this parliament in expressing our deepest condolences and sorrow for the 15 innocent lives taken by the horrific terror attack,” Ms Ley said.  “Surely this is something that happens elsewhere, not in Australia.  “Ordinary people became heroes.  “We must unite as a parliament to confront and defeat this evil.  “Radical Islamist extremism caused this. I repeat, Radical Islamist extremism caused this. Leaders need to be able to express this clearly because if you can’t name the problem, you can’t defeat it.  “It should not have taken the murder of 15 people for us to open our eyes to the dangers of antisemitism in Australia.”

title: ‘Australians are angry’: Littleproud responds to One Nation polling surge
description: Nationals Leader David Littleproud claims One Nation’s polling surge demonstrates the “anger across the electorate”.  “There’s always lessons in polls,” Mr Littleproud told Sky News Australia.  “I think it demonstrates the Australian people are angry, angry with the direction of the country.”

title: World Economic Forum shockingly invite Iran minister to summit as regime slaughters civilians
description: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is facing mounting calls to exclude members of the Iranian regime ahead of the Davos summit this week.  On Friday, the United Against Nuclear Iran (UANI) watchdog group sent a letter to WEF President Borge Brende.  The letter to the WEF’s president urged the group not to invite any members of the Islamic Republic of Iran after the country slaughtered its civilians.  Rather than removing any Iranian officials from the list, the WEF added an interview with the country’s Foreign Minister, Abbas Araghchi, to the schedule.  UANI CEO, Mark Wallace, cited reports of human rights violations by the Ayatollah Ali Khamenei regime against Iranian civilians.

title: Chuck Schumer claims he has 'bipartisan support' to reverse some DOGE cuts
description: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has vowed to reverse some Department of Government Efficiency [DOGE] cuts.  The reversal of the cuts mainly relates to budgets for Transportation, as well as Housing and Urban Development.  Schumer’s comments came during a forum held by the Center for American Progress.  The House minority leader also said more money could be funnelled into the programs that were slashed by DOGE.  Schumer also claims he has “bipartisan support” for his new budget, which will undo the cuts.

title: ‘Change is here’: Barnaby Joyce responds to One Nation support surge
description: One Nation MP Barnaby Joyce says he feels “humbled” by One Nation’s support surge in the recent Newspoll.  “It’s an indication polling, it’s not a vote,” Mr Joyce told Sky News Australia.  “The work is still in front of us, but there is a change in politics.  "Change is not coming; the change is here."

title: ‘Very difficult to see a compromise’: Denmark not going to ‘give up’ Greenland to Trump
description: Former Denmark defence adviser Mikkel Vedby Rasmussen claims Denmark isn’t going to “give up” Greenland to the United States amid President Donald Trump’s push.  “Greenland is an integrated part of the Kingdom of Denmark, and it’s going to remain so,” he told Sky News Australia.  “I think it’s very difficult to see a compromise on the Greenlanders’ right to decide their own fate.”

title: ‘Overwhelming majority’ of Greenlanders believe they should ‘choose their own path’
description: Former Denmark defence adviser Mikkel Vedby Rasmussen claims the overwhelming majority of Greenlanders feel they “belong in the Kingdom of Denmark” and that they should “choose their own path”.  “Greenland is a vibrant democracy,” he told Sky News Australia.  “Overwhelming majority of Greenlanders feel that they belong in the Kingdom of Denmark, and they most certainly believe that they should choose their own path.”

title: ‘I would give that very keen consideration’: Joel Fitzgibbon in the mix for US ambassador role
description: Former Labor cabinet minister Joel Fitzgibbon has responded to reports of his name being mentioned as a favourite in the mix to become the next US ambassador once Kevin Rudd steps down at the end of March.  “I haven’t had any conversation with the prime minister or the foreign minister on this issue,” he told Sky News Australia.  “If any prime minister asked me to serve the nation again in some capacity, of course, I would give that very keen consideration.”

title: Minneapolis Mayor’s ICE meltdown on CNN sparks devastating roast online
description: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey has unleashed on Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents as they continue to crack down on his city.  In an interview on CNN’s ‘State of the Union’, Jake Tapper questioned the Democratic mayor on whether he thought Minneapolis was being “occupied” by the federal government.  Jacob Frey doubled down on his rhetoric, saying not only “invaded” but also “under siege and occupied”.  The Minneapolis mayor said that the second ICE agents leave Minneapolis, the city would be met with “calm”.  His comments have sparked significant backlash on social media, with many blasting his “incompetence” and others labelling him a “radical lefty”.

title: Trump putting 'America first’ with ‘peace through strength’ ideology
description: US Pollster Nicholas Weinstein praises US President Donald Trump for putting America first.   “President Trump's not going to blunder us into a 20-year forever conflict,” Mr Weinstein told Sky News Australia.  “He’s going to move with force to protect American interests.   “You can be America first just with peace through strength.”

title: New York City residents brace for more snow
description: New York City residents are preparing for more disruptions as another snowstorm approaches the northeast of the US.  While some residents are trying to keep their footpaths and driveways clear despite the forecast for more snow to come.  Residents spent their Saturday stocking up on salt and shovels as they prepared for another snowstorm.

title: Trump administration ‘looking for the right opportunity’ for military action in Iran
description: Former White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney says the Trump administration is “looking for the right opportunity” to strike Iran.  "It's a once in a generational type of opportunity," Mr Mulvaney told Sky News Australia.  “If you can solve the Iranian problem, not only does the Middle East become a better place, but the rest of the world becomes better as well.  “The Trump administration is looking for the right opportunity, they’re just not ready yet.”

title: China threatens Australia with trade sanctions for not supporting Taiwan’s reunification
description: China’s ambassador to Australia is calling on the federal government to support the reunification of China and Taiwan.  Xiao Qian says Australia cannot keep reaping the benefits of trade with China while seeking to block reunification.  He has cautioned the government against pursuing dialogue on Taiwan unless they were committed to reunification, signalling economic consequences.  “Taiwan is a province of China, just as Tasmania is a state of Australia. This is the only correct understanding of ‘one China’,” Mr Qian said.

title: Chile declares state of catastrophe as wildfires rage across the country
description: Wildfires have continued to wreak havoc and rage across central and southern Chile, leaving much of the country under heat alerts.  Chile’s President Gabriel Boric has declared a state of catastrophe in the country’s central Biobio region and neighbouring Nuble region.  The regions, about 500 kilometres south of Chile’s capital, Santiago, have been plagued by wildfires raging across the country.  At least 18 people have reportedly been killed, and at least 20,000 people have been evacuated.  Disaster officials say about 250 homes have been destroyed by the wildfires as they scorch thousands of hectares of land.

title: Kristi Noem bashes Tim Walz for his criticism of ICE investigation procedures
description: US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem has blasted Minnesota Governor Tim Walz.  Noem’s comments came during a CBS ‘Face the Nation’ interview with Margaret Brennan.  The homeland security secretary’s scathing comments came when she was asked about Walz’s remarks on investigating the shooting of Renee Good.  Noem said the incident was being investigated using the Biden-era procedure.  The Homeland Security Secretary then goes on to attack the Minnesota Governor, citing his “very bad track record”.  Noem then references the welfare fraud scandal that is embroiling the state, finishing by saying she “would not take advice” from him.
